You‚Äôve come to the right place. Join us as we look at the top 10 platforms and tools for startups you should be using in the year ahead. If you have an eCommerce business, you need all the help you can get to grow. This is especially true if you don‚Äôt have a big budget, or a team of staff to support you. With this in mind, we‚Äôve put together a guide to our top ten eCommerce platforms and top ten eCommerce tools. The current list is an addition to our Workbench for a startup The top 10 startup platforms and tools to use this year The right eCommerce platform can make or break your startup. There is a wide range of eCommerce platforms out there with many different features. Here are our top ten eCommerce sites and how they could benefit your business. Shopify; Wix; Squarespace; Adobe Commerce (powered by Magento); BigCommerce; WooCommerce; Weebly; Prestashop; Volution; WordPress. 1. Shopify Shopify is one of the most well-known and loved eCommerce platforms in the world. Startups of all shapes and sizes are fans because it‚Äôs easy to use and makes customizing an online store as easy as possible. One of the things we like the most about Shopify is that it lets you import products from other eCommerce platforms. This means if you used another eCommerce platform for your startup, but things didn‚Äôt work out, you don‚Äôt have to create your products again. Prices range from $29 to $299 a month, with a free 14-day trial. 2. Wix Similar to Shopify, Wix is another eCommerce platform that is simple to use and easy to set up. A lot of the customization is done through drag and drop, meaning that no coding knowledge is needed. Another advantage Wix has is that you can set up marketing automation. This means you can send shoppers a friendly reminder if they add an item to their cart but don‚Äôt buy it, helping to boost your conversion rates. Prices for Wix‚Äôs eCommerce plan range from $18 to $30 a month. 3. Squarespace Squarespace has become extremely popular with startups in recent years, thanks to its excellent customer support, stunning templates, and ease of use. One of the advantages Squarespace has over other eCommerce platforms is the ability to manage inventory. You can amend stock levels, get alerts when a product is running low, and even set up waiting lists to let shoppers know when a sold-out item is back in stock. Prices for Squarespace‚Äôs eCommerce plan range from $28 to $41 a month. 4. Adobe Commerce (powered by Magento) Formerly known as Magento, you need web development skills to make the most out of Adobe Commerce. However, if you have them, it is one of the most scalable and flexible eCommerce platforms around. Adobe Commerce has a lot of features you can use to make your eCommerce site stand out, including reward points, gift registries, and the option to promote product bundles. Users also comment that it is particularly good for SEO, increasing the odds of getting to the first page of the search engine results. Pricing is available on request. 5. BigCommerce One of the great things about BigCommerce is the scalability it provides. This means that you can start using it as a small eCommerce business, and the platform will grow and evolve as you do. It also looks great and is fully responsive on a smartphone, something which is very important to shoppers considering one out of every two purchases is now made on a mobile device. Prices range from $29.95 to $299.95 a month, with a free 15-day trial. 6. WooCommerce Another one of the major players in the eCommerce platform market, WooCommerce has a lot of rich features that will easily adapt to your startup, no matter which industry you are in. Unlike the other platforms on this list, WooCommerce is slightly different as it is built into WordPress, meaning you can easily incorporate it into your existing WP site. WooCommerce is free to use, but you can pay for additional features. 7. Weebly Weebly is one of the most cost-effective options on this list, making it a good option for startups on a smaller budget. However, just because it is cheaper, doesn‚Äôt mean it lacks functionality. The eCommerce platform is well-known for having lots of attractive template designs to choose from, as well as the ability to send emails from within the platform. The basic option is free, with prices increasing to $25 a month. 8. Prestashop Like Weebly, Prestashop is another one of the cheaper options available, but this certainly shouldn‚Äôt take it out of the running for your business! The platform itself is completely free; you just pay for any premium themes and modules you would like to use on your website. This means you can completely customize your site to look and behave exactly how you want. 9. Volusion Volusion is best known for its excellent customer service. This means that if you need a little extra support getting your new eCommerce site up and running, this eCommerce platform has you covered. Another advantage of this platform is its ease of use, making it simple to add new product descriptions and images. Prices range from $29 to $299 a month, with a free 14-day trial. 10. WordPress While WordPress isn‚Äôt an eCommerce site builder as such, it does have a lot of plugins (like WooCommerce) you can use to integrate shopping onto your website. If you‚Äôre already used to building sites in WordPress (and bear in mind that about one in three sites is built on the WP platform), this can be a huge advantage. WordPress is free to use, but you may have to purchase some eCommerce plugins. The top ten tools for startups in 2022 Once you have your eCommerce platform sorted, you will want to find some great tools to use alongside it. Here are our top ten eCommerce tools which will add extra functionality to your business. Google Analytics; Slack; Mockplus; Optimizely; Veeqo; Smile.io; Buffer; Oberlo; Unbxd; Mailchimp. 1. Google Analytics No eCommerce platform is complete without Google Analytics. Free to use and easy to install, this tool will help you see which pages web users are visiting, what products people are buying and how shoppers are searching on your site. 2. Slack Whether you have a team working from home, or a collection of freelancers and consultants you need to keep in contact with, Slack makes it easy to stay connected. It also comes with a mobile app so you can send messages and hold meetings while you‚Äôre on the go. Slack is free to use, but you can pay between $7.15 and $13.28 a month for additional functionality, including unlimited message storage. 3. Mockplus When you‚Äôre designing your eCommerce site, a wireframe design is a fantastic way to determine what needs to go where on your pages. Mockplus makes it simple to put together a prototype of your website that you can use when creating your site or, alternatively, give to your web developer. Prices range from $199 to $9999 a year. If you prefer, you can buy a license to use the software as long as you like. 4. Optimizely A/B testing is a valuable way of seeing what works on your eCommerce site and what needs improving. You have two pages, each with one key difference and then see which one members of the public respond to the best. This ensures that your store looks and functions well on smartphones and tablets, providing a seamless shopping experience for your customers. Secure Payment Processing: Security is paramount in ecommerce. Look for platforms that offer security features, including SSL certificates and PCI compliance, to protect your customers' payment information and build trust. Look for platforms that offer 24/7 support through various channels, such as live chat, email, and phone, to help you resolve issues quickly. Scalability: As your business grows, your ecommerce platform should be able to scale with you. Look for platforms that offer flexible plans, can handle unlimited products, and can handle increased traffic and sales bandwidth without compromising performance. Analytics and Reporting: Access to detailed analytics and reporting tools helps you track your store's performance, understand customer behavior, and make data-driven decisions. Look for platforms that offer dashboards, a content management system, and customizable reports. Ecommerce Platforms for Startups FAQs Here are some commonly asked questions about ecommerce platforms for startups. Do ecommerce platforms for startups support mobile commerce? Yes, most modern ecommerce platforms support mobile commerce (m-commerce). This is crucial as more consumers shop via smartphones and tablets. A good ecommerce platform should offer mobile-responsive design templates, ensuring that your online store looks and functions well on all devices. Additionally, mobile payment integrations and features like mobile-optimized checkout pages can improve the shopping experience and reduce cart abandonment. Customer support is very important when choosing an ecommerce platform, especially for startups that may not have in-house technical expertise. Look for platforms that offer 24/7 support, comprehensive documentation, and access to a community or knowledge base. A corporate culture definition comprises both the mundane and the intangible. It is more than merely identity, industry, or branding. It stems from a company‚Äôs common beliefs and values, expressed in its everyday practices. Which elements constitute corporate culture? Here are but a few of them: typical employee behaviors, including interactions with clients and customers management styles and hierarchy (or lack thereof) day-to-day business practices personnel decisions, leave policies, and employee perks elements of workspace organization, such as seating arrangements or dress codes 4 types of company culture for your organization The Competing Values Framework came from extensive academic research into corporate organizational styles. It describes 4 types of corporate culture: hierarchy culture, adhocracy culture, clan culture, and market culture. Source: Page #3 of Dr. Kim Cameron‚Äôs report, ‚ÄúAn Introduction to the Competing Values Framework.‚Äù While your company may use some combination of these culture styles, it‚Äôs likely that one of them will dominate. Hierarchy culture Perhaps the most instantly recognizable, classic example of corporate culture revolves around a hierarchy. It emphasizes the separation of workers from middle management and executives. It delineates the distinctions between departments. Its processes and procedures have been etched in stone, since time immemorial. A stereotypical example of hierarchy culture is a federal government workplace. The antithesis of hierarchy culture is adhocracy culture. Pros: Roles and responsibilities are clearly defined. If business needs remain static, the hierarchy provides a certain efficiency. After all, no one has to spend time re-inventing the proverbial wheel. Cons: The rigidity of hierarchy culture makes re-evaluation, change, and adaptability nearly impossible. It can choke attempts at innovation or ‚Äúoutside-the-box‚Äù thinking. Rather than working together cooperatively, different departments can become siloed. This hampers cross-functional collaboration. Adhocracy culture In Latin, ad hoc means something done for a special or specific purpose. It usually refers to a temporary, makeshift solution. This is the essence of an adhocracy. As in agile methodology, adhocracy structure is flexible and adaptable. It can be changed on the fly. As new business or management challenges arise, an adhocracy re-evaluates and re-configures itself in response to evolving needs. Rather than following a conventional chain of command, employees are encouraged to take the most expeditious route to solve a problem. This can mean improvising solutions, bypassing checks and balances, or working directly with C-suite executives to solve workday issues. Pros: Adhocracy culture stresses efficiency over titles and bureaucracy. It is designed to adapt and pivot, as needed. Cons: Compared to a more traditional management hierarchy, the flat organizational structure may be confusing or intimidating. Upper management may focus more on addressing day-to-day operational concerns than big-picture strategizing. Lines of project ownership and accountability can quickly become blurred. Market culture When you think of market culture, picture Gordon Gekko of the movie Wall Street, with his aggressive ‚Äúgreed is good‚Äù motto. While market culture isn‚Äôt necessarily so cutthroat, it‚Äôs definitely focused on profit and achievement above all else. Whether within the broader industry or the confines of the company itself, co-workers compete for recognition. Winning awards and landing ‚Äúwales‚Äù are the markers of success. Pros: High performance is emphasized. Intense competition among colleagues can mean that the company will win big, since everyone is trying to outshine everyone else in the office. Cons: By putting performance over cooperation, a market culture could create an atmosphere of tension and mistrust among colleagues. Workplace ethics might get muddied or outright eschewed. Clan culture No, we‚Äôre not talking Clash of Clans here! Rather than spotlighting performance and competition, clan culture centers around building an almost familial atmosphere in the workplace. Clan culture emphasizes corporate values such as cooperation, loyalty, and connection. Coworkers often bond at activities like company picnics and game nights. The company encourages complete employee devotion to the corporate mission, in the workplace and beyond. Management supports the needs of individual staff members through policies like open leave, tuition reimbursement, and other employee perks. Mentorship and job enrichment are common management tools in clan culture to nurture employees in their career growth. Like adhocracy culture, clan culture often relies on a flat organizational structure. In this case, the lack of organizational formality is meant to make workers feel more comfortable when approaching management. Pros: The supportive working environment of clan culture is built on trust and transparency. Employee engagement and satisfaction tend to be high, leading to long-term loyalty. Cons: Clan culture can create an echo chamber in which there is no room for dissenting opinions. This can cause blind spots and reduce innovation. Perceived outsiders might be regarded with mistrust. Over-emphasis on consensus can drag out decision-making. The lack of boundaries and management structure can lead to a breakdown of leadership authority. Why you need to establish a corporate culture in your organization Corporate cultures can be like cities: Some are deliberately planned, and others simply evolve. A nebulous or undefined corporate culture can be a detriment. Before its elements can be modified or improved to meet business challenges, they need to be clearly identified. If this is not done, your company may struggle to remain viable. To attract top talent High-performing professionals often garner primo job offers. They will likely seek a corporate culture promoting career growth, flexible benefits, and a satisfying work-life balance. In addition, topflight talent tends to expect a culture of respect, where they feel their considerable skills and contributions are valued. To foster employee engagement and productivity The degree of individual investment in the company‚Äôs goals and mission can be characterized as employee engagement. Ranging from the active engagement of superstar, high-performing employees to the active disengagement of employees who barely contribute, the level of employee engagement is often driven by company culture. In cultures where employees feel confident and valued ‚Äì such as clan cultures ‚Äì their engagement increases. They become more invested and productive. Employees often feel more valued when their companies invest in their futures. This might be through a benefit such as contribution matching for retirement accounts, workplace mentoring, or ongoing corporate training. Regular opportunities for upskilling and reskilling are highly valued by employees as career builders. Corporate language training, in particular, can increase employee engagement and productivity. It also stimulates creativity and improves concentration, which can certainly lead to better productivity in the workplace. To support employee retention Employee engagement is closely related to employee retention. After all, engaged employees usually stick around longer than apathetic ones. There are many benefits of employee retention. Among these are improved customer relationships, increased productivity, and savings on training costs. Ways to support employee retention include: competitive benefits packages flexible working options opportunities for career growth To streamline the decision-making process Management policies that provide clear, value-based guidelines for decision-making can minimize ambiguity and uncertainty. This will ensure that decisions are made efficiently. Such a corporate culture also aligns decisions with the company‚Äôs vision and values, while supporting its mission. To increase customer satisfaction While much of corporate culture is focused internally, it‚Äôs equally important to consider the needs of customers. Companies can increase customer satisfaction and retention by listening to customers‚Äô concerns, addressing them fairly, and treating them with respect at all times. This will protect your company‚Äôs investment in customer acquisition costs and lead to more repeat customers. To improve the company‚Äôs reputation A corporate culture communicating values such as honesty, transparency, and fairness will build a positive reputation. It will likely retain existing customers and staff. By building a solid reputation, it can become both a trusted brand and a sought-after employer. Final words The time and effort needed to establish or redefine your corporate culture is one of the most important investments you can make in your company‚Äôs future. With careful consideration, you can create a corporate culture that represents your company‚Äôs values in the best way possible. You can attract and retain top talent and increase your customer base, all while working toward the fulfilment of your company‚Äôs mission. A good corporate culture reflects your company‚Äôs values and equips it to effectively fulfill its mission. It respects employees and customers alike, functioning in a positive and ethical manner. Improving corporate culture involves making an inventory of what your current culture offers employees and customers, as well as how it serves your company‚Äôs mission.
